I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  help  the  Government  of 
Mongolia develop a sustainable and economically viable fodder industry. The TA will raise 
technical capacity and increase knowledge to address industry issues of (i) a fodder demand–
supply gap and (ii) guidelines and quality standards for production, processing, storage, and 
supply to ensure sustainable fodder management. A sustainable fodder industry will help herders 
build resilience against climate risks and help fodder producers develop the agribusiness value 
chain, which all contribute to opportunities to improve income generation and diversify the 
economy. 
 
2.  The government requested TA from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to support the 
sustainable development of its fodder industry.1 The TA is included in the country operations 
business plan for Mongolia, 2020–2021.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Mongolia relies heavily on its agriculture sector, which contributes over 12% of its gross 
domestic product. Livestock’s share in agriculture output is 84.2%: it provides employment to one 
third of Mongolia’s economically active population and involves 230,800 herder households.3 
Livestock numbers have increased to 66.46 million, with meat and milk as the primary products.4 
The livestock industry remains an important priority to reduce rural poverty, boost incomes, and 
diversify economic growth by producing food and exporting high-quality meat and wool products, 
yet productivity remains low. Degraded pastureland and the lack of an adequate quantity and 
quality of feed resources are among the major factors causing poor livestock productivity.5 With 
increasing livestock numbers, it is important to ensure fodder resources can support higher stock 
numbers; can manage the seasonal variation in production, supply, and demand; and do not 
cause a decline in pastureland quality and livestock health from poor nutrition. At present, fodder 
resources do not meet these conditions. 
 
4.  Livestock fodder comprises unprocessed or processed forms of native hay; planted hay 
from annual and perennial grasses and legumes; fodder crops such as barley, oats, corn, beans 
and sunflowers; and crop by-products such as bran. Since the transition from the planned to 
market economy in 1990, with an extended absence of management and investment, the 
livestock product market and the provision of inputs and services to it have drastically decreased.  
Herders now have the responsibility to secure inputs and services, however they lack the skills 
and incentives to take up activities for supplementary feed and fodder production. The limited 
supply has been compounded by herders and farmers considering fodder production to be a high-
risk activity because of unfavorable weather conditions, limited production areas with adequate 
infrastructure, outdated technology and equipment, and limited market opportunities. 
  
 
1    The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 4 September 2019. 
2   ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: Mongolia, 2020–2021. Manila. 
3   National Statistics Office of Mongolia. 2017. Mongolian Statistical Yearbook 2017. Ulaanbaatar.   
4   Livestock composition is 46.0% sheep, 40.8% goats, 6.6% cattle, 5.9% horses and 0.7% camels. Livestock are 
distributed through all aimags (provinces), with camel and goat production emphasized in the southern Gobi aimags, 
horse production emphasized in the north, south central, and eastern aimags, and cattle production emphasized in 
the northern aimags. Sheep production is relatively evenly distributed throughout the country. 
5   Pastures represent 96.3% of Mongolia’s 115.8 million hectare of agricultural land. However, about 70% of the 
pastures are degraded and have seen a reduction of up to 80% of plant-based biomass in the Mongolian steppe 
grassland ecosystems.

2 
5.  The availability of high-quality fodder is crucial for Mongolia to develop and upgrade its 
livestock sector because improved, higher quality fodder production with a stable supply will 
improve animal nutrition and health and reduce animal mortalities. Improved livestock health will 
result in higher quality meat and fiber products and provide increased resilience and security 
against dzuds (extreme winter weather conditions), which causes large stock losses. At present, 
fodder production is insufficient, of low quality, with unreliable product supply. In 2016, the fodder 
market was worth about $120 million  and although domestic supply accounted for 98% of the 
available product on the market, it only meets 86% of roughage demand and 51% demand for 
concentrates. 6 With livestock numbers estimated to increase by 5% to 10% per year, with 
increasing intensified livestock farming (dairy, beef, pig, and poultry farms) and demand for high-
quality feed (concentrates, silage, high-protein feeds, green fodder, and grains), the demand far 
exceeds current production capacity levels. An estimated additional $19 million–$23 million per 
year in fodder resources will be needed to meet the demand.7 
 
6.  Government policy aims to help increase domestic fodder production rather than increase 
imports. Crop policies and crop farmers are giving more attention to the need to increase fodder 
cropping. However, without a conducive policy environment, technical know-how, and private 
sector  engagement,  domestic  fodder  producers  remain  constrained  in  filling  the  gaps  in 
production, processing, and storage across the diverse agro-ecological regions.8 Furthermore, 
because most of the arable land is degraded, and equipment and infrastructure limited and 
outdated, it will be a challenge to increase domestic production levels. A new approach to promote 
fodder production and industry management is required for a sustainable fodder industry that will 
help  herders  build  resilience  against  climate  risks  and  help  fodder  producers  develop  the 
agribusiness value chain. 
 
7.  An integrated approach to land, pasture, and fodder management, with improved herd 
management and increased resilience to climate change, will be fundamental to the industry’s 
long-term sustainability. The integrated approach aims to improve the feed supply and also 
emphasize the need for a sustainable balance between livestock numbers on one hand and 
pastureland quality and livestock feed availability on the other hand. This approach should 
address the need for: (i) increasing knowledge and capabilities to manage natural resources and 
their  relationship  to  fodder  production;  (ii)  strengthening  institutional  coordination  among 
government agencies, fodder producers, and herder groups; (iii) improving extension services for 
knowledge  transfer,  awareness  raising,  and  capacity  building;  (iv)  building  on  institutional 
arrangements, such as through cooperatives and private sector engagement to support the fodder 
value chain; (v) monitoring and coordinating fodder supply with livestock movements to match 
supply with demand, including logistics, transportation, and storage; and (vi) raising awareness 
among stakeholders to encourage industry coordination and foster a positive attitude about 
engaging in sustainable fodder management. To address these needs, the TA will generate new 
technical knowledge, build capacity, and raise awareness about natural resources management 
to facilitate the adoption of sustainable fodder production and value chain development, promote 
institutional coordination, and propose enabling policies.  
 
 
6    The fodder market is composed of 1.18 million tons of roughage, 38,100 tons of fodder, 105,600 tons of mineral 
fodder, and 94,300 tons of concentrates, of which only $5.4 million  worth came from imported concentrate products 
(8%) and roughage (2%). 
7   Erdenebolor Baast. 2017. Market Study on Livestock Fodder Production and Demand in Mongolia.  
8    The five major agro-ecological zones of the Central and Eastern Steppe, Gobi Desert, Hangai-Khuvsgul, Mongolian 
Altai, and Selenge-onon have distinct geographic patterns and agricultural production potential and requirements.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: sustainable and economically viable fodder 
industry in Mongolia improved (Mongolia Sustainable Development Vision 2030).9 The TA will 
have the following outcome: sustainable fodder management practices (production, processing, 
storage, and supply) adopted.10 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output  1:  Fodder  production,  supply,  and  demand  assessed.  The  diagnostic 
assessment will apply a spatial approach—including the use of remote sensing and smartphone 
based observations, field survey, and literature review—to survey the ecological regions of 
Mongolia to (i) assess the current fodder production and market on the composition, use, and 
nutritional value of indigenous and imported fodder grass species in pastureland and irrigated 
land; (ii) review current fodder production practices in growing, harvesting, quality testing, and 
storage; (iii) evaluate land use for potential new fodder production area expansion; and (iv) 
evaluate fodder supply against the dynamic demand of feed by varying livestock population and 
species, considering nutrient values, and identifying the surpluses and deficits. The assessment 
will also identify the policy, market, institutional, economic, and social factors affecting fodder 
production and trade, as well as the risks facing farmers, herders, and traders. Based on the 
assessment, the TA will propose recommendations to improve the production, supply, and sector 
management of the Mongolia fodder industry. 
 
10.  Output 2: Technical solutions for sustainable fodder management developed. This 
output will assess and propose technologies, quality standards, guidelines, and trainings for 
sustainable fodder management. It will focus on addressing the technical know-how required to 
increase  fodder  production  and  improve  harvesting,  processing,  and  storage  techniques, 
technologies, and capacities. Key topics include: (i) indigenous and imported high-quality hay and 
fodder varieties which are suitable to the local environment with enhanced climate resilience, 
along with good agronomic practices; (ii) improved harvesting and processing procedures such 
as nutrient add-ons; (iii) improved storage practices which can prolong the nutritional quality of 
fodder  under  varying  storage  conditions;  (iv)  guidelines  on  improved  practices  for  fodder 
harvesting, processing, and storage; and (v) fodder quality standards and testing procedures. 
Based on the recommendations, the TA will develop a training and awareness raising program 
targeting fodder producers, processors, storage facilities, herders, and extension workers. 
 
11.  Output 3: Enabling policies and action plans formulated. This output will focus on 
providing policy recommendations and a fodder sector development action plan to improve fodder 
management. The output will identify policy domains and prioritize investment needs to ensure 
reliable and quality fodder production in Mongolia. Key considerations will include institutional 
strengthening to integrate multi-agency collaborations; monitoring and forecasting of fodder 
production, demand, quality, and nutritional requirements; access to and sustainable use of 
natural resources for fodder cultivation; supply and demand trends for fodder, herder, and 
livestock migrations; provision of extension services at aimag (province) and soum (district) 
governments; and an awareness campaign on safe and efficient use of feed and sustainable 
fodder management. 
 
9   Government of Mongolia. 2016. Mongolia Sustainable Development Vision 2030. Ulaanbaatar. 
10   The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
 
12.  Lessons learned. The TA builds on lessons from previous project support to the livestock 
sector, noting the need to: (i) coordinate technical assistance between donor and development 
agencies not only to provide technical expertise, but also to build institutional capacity to ensure 
results can be mainstreamed within government agencies to ensure continuation of activities and 
improve the sustainability of outputs; (ii) involve senior national and soum government officials, 
concerned government agencies, and local experts in the TA work to ensure quality outputs that 
meet the needs of various stakeholders; and (iii) strategically plan dissemination to enhance 
knowledge-sharing activities and showcase the findings and recommendations, to generate 
greater benefits.  
 
13.  Strategic  fit.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  Government  of  Mongolia’s  Sustainable 
Development Vision 2030 to develop productive farming and livestock sectors (footnote 9). It 
addresses the Action Program of the Government for 2016–2020 to establish regional livestock 
fodder industry and increase the reserve of hay and fodder. The design of the TA follows ADB’s 
Operational Plans for Agriculture and Natural Resources; ADB’s country partnership strategy for 
Mongolia, 2017–2020; and ADB’s Strategy 2030, which aims to promote poverty reduction, rural 
development, inclusive growth, and sustainable agriculture practices, particularly through operational 
priorities  for tackling  climate  change,  building climate and  disaster resilience, and  enhancing 
environmental sustainability promoting rural development and food security.11  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.1 million, of which $1.0 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 2. 
   
15.  The  following  are  ineligible  items  under  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction:  (i) 
purchase of vehicles, (ii) salaries for civil servants, (iii) foreign travel, (iv) scholarships or long 
internships, (v) detailed engineering design, (vi) civil works and other related expenses, and (vii) 
those under ADB’s List of Ineligible Items (or Negative List) and Prohibited Investment Activities 
List.12 
 
16.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of remuneration and travel 
expenses  of  counterpart  staff;  domestic  transportation;  government  data  and  geographic 
information  system  maps  and  studies  for  the  TA  consultants’  use;  office  accommodation, 
including use of meeting rooms, and office facilities; and other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB  will  administer  the  TA,  coordinate  its  implementation  through  the  East  Asia 
Department, and work closely with Ministry of Food, Agriculture, and Light Industry (MOFALI) 
counterparts. ADB will engage the consultants. The consultants will carry out procurement 
following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated 
project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. The implementation arrangements are 
summarized in the table.

18.  Consulting services. ADB will engage a consulting firm following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions, using a simplified technical proposal and the quality- and cost-based 
selection method.13 The quality–cost ratio will be 90:10 because of the high technical complexity 
of the consulting assignment. Disbursement of the TA proceeds will follow ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The consultants will 
submit progress reports, which will be reviewed by ADB and the government. 
 
19.  The TA will require 74 person-months of international and national consulting services. 
ADB will recruit a firm to provide expertise, consisting of a fodder development specialist as team 
leader (national), two international consultants (a fodder specialist and a fodder post-harvest 
specialist), and seven national consultants (an agricultural value chain specialist, agronomist, 
irrigation planning specialist, economist, financial specialist, policy and institutions specialist, and 
an administrative assistant).  MOFALI and ADB in consultation with the firm will review the need 
for additional consultant during implementation, and if required will propose resource persons for 
the TA and recruit them on an as-needed basis to review the consultants’ outputs and share 
knowledge, following ADB’s guidelines on recruiting and administering resource persons. 
 
20.  ADB’s procurement. Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff 
instructions and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to 
time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved provision 
of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Mongolia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 
for Sustainable Fodder Management, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Fodder production, supply, and demand assessed 
1.1. Assess current production and market on the composition, use, and nutritional value of indigenous and 
imported fodder grass species across ecological regions through survey and testing by month 7.  
1.2. Review current fodder policies and management practices, including growing in pastureland and 
irrigated land, harvesting, and storage, by month 7. 
1.3. Evaluate the potential for increasing fodder production in spatial details, with focus on irrigated fodder 
production, by month 8.  
1.4. Assess the dynamic fodder supply versus demand and map spatial and temporal shortages and excess 
for optimal design of production and animal stocking management by month 9. 
1.5. Draft report on baseline assessment on policies, market, institutional, economic, social, and biophysical 
factors in fodder production and trade by month 10. 
 
2.  Technical solutions for sustainable fodder management developed 
2.1. Identify and recommend climate and disease resilient high-yield seed varieties suitable for local 
cultivation in different agroecological regions of Mongolia by month 20. 
2.2. Develop improved fodder harvesting schedule and methods and processing procedures, such as 
nutrient add-ons, packaging materials and methods, by month 12. 
2.3. Recommend improved storage practices including infrastructure, management practices, and shelf life 
by month 18. 
2.4. Develop draft guidelines on fodder production, harvesting, processing, and storage by month 18. 
2.5. Develop draft national quality standards for fodder products to guide production, manufacturing, and 
trade by month 18. 
2.6. Conduct trainings for fodder growers, herders, entrepreneurs, and government extension services on 
the guidelines and quality standards developed above by month 22. 
 
3.  Enabling policies and action plans formulated  
3.1. Develop actionable policy recommendations on sustainable fodder management for Mongolia livestock 
and farming sector by month 20. 
3.2. Conduct awareness campaigns on the importance of fodder for livestock with leaflets, brochures, 
signpost, and online activities by month 24.

Prepare the interim report and conduct the interim workshop by month 12. 
Prepare the draft final report and conduct the final workshop by month 20. 
Carry out knowledge dissemination by month 23.
